I just want to share this small piece of feedback I just got from a friend who attended some Backdrop CMS discussions with me, started his project in Backdrop CMS and worked on it for a while. I just asked him if he was still using Backdrop (about 6 months after last communication. Here is his short reply (I don't have any more info):

"Nope, no more Backdrop. I ended up switching to Drupal 8 mainly for the API stuff and a couple other modules I can't remember. But my time with Backdrop made Drupal 8 much less intimidating. I then scaled down my ambitions and have currently been focusing on what I already had in Shopify."

Clearly, this tidbit of feedback is not all that useful. I hope to ask him more questions later. But, I think it's interesting to remember that not everyone who tries Backdrop and Drupal 8, sticks with Backdrop.
For me it really depends on both the project and the client. I recently got to play with Webform in Drupal 8 and it blew my mind

I find that natural. I've been always saying that Backdrop is also an in-between solution for those not ready to go D8 (for whatever reason: budget, time/energy, skills etc.) ...I expect that some of the people will simply take the time to familiarize themselves with D8/9 and then perhaps move on. ...I also expect that many of these people may use both D8/9 and Backdrop, depending on the size of the project.
...all that is perfectly good :+1:
I use both, too.
@Olaf Grabienski Will you continue using both if Zulip is made the official channel?
@BWPanda (Peter) "both" was for D8 and Backdrop
...this is the "Drupal 8" thread :sweat_smile:
Oh, ha! Came straight after the Zulip thread in the General stream :smile:

I still find Backdrop superior to D8 in every way that counts for me and for my clients. We have yet to pick up a client for which D8/9 is a good fit, and I don't anticipate doing so. Backdrop has proven to be a very good fit for us for the more complex sites or ecommerce sites where Wordpress isn't the way to go. It's a lot more scaleable than D8/9 in that it can be used for small to midsize sites without issues of added development or larger than necessary hosting requirements to handle the back end. D8/9 is built for the high end - large enterprise. It doesn't scale down well.

Backdrop has proven to be a very good fit for us for the more complex sites or ecommerce sites where Wordpress isn't the way to go.

@Elisabeth Garbeil What ecommerce solutions do/have you used in Backdrop? I haven't needed any yet, but likely will in future...

@BWPanda (Peter) Ubercart works great! It handled all our use cases so far on Backdrop. I've only needed to use Drupal Commerce 2 times in a decade and found it unwieldy. Ubercart is mostly set up and handles all but a few situations. It's a lot easier and cheaper for most of our clients. Both cases where we needed Commerce, I would go in a different direction if I could do it over and only one was primarily a store. For the store, the ROI wasn't good for the client (it cost too much to set up for them) and they ended up shutting it down after a couple of years. For the other, I'm not sure what I would do - part of it was the kludge that you get with dealing with any nonprofit. What they wanted didn't match their budget. That's part of what made the switch to Backdrop easy. Ubercart wasn't supported on D8 yet anyway. It now is, but I'm not crazy about the D8 version. Commerce is better on D8 than on D7, but it isn't any less time intensive to set up or maintain.
Good to know Ubercart works well. I haven't used that since probably D6 (used Commerce otherwise). Will look into it if I need an ecommerce solution for Backdrop.

...simple huh? I've worked on many issues in our queue where we swapped machine names for human-readable names in the UI, and it usually took a few (5-10, maybe even less) lines of code.

:laughing:
Another good one: https://www.drupal.org/docs/9/how-drupal-9-is-made-and-what-is-included/what-are-the-new-features-of-drupal-9
Drupal 9.0 will have the same features as the final minor release of Drupal 8
:sweat_smile: ...oh good! ...what a nice marketing pitch: "upgrade to the new version to get ...well, nothing new"

I've been offered a position at an organization that uses D8. They've got a couple D7 sites and a WordPress one. So how bad is D8 really? I totally have not worked with it much. It means not seeing the Backdrop site I'm working through to the finish line but the new organization is in the Midwest, where I've wanted to move back to for a long time.

I've built three D8 sites a few years ago, and I still maintain them. I wouldn't say D8 is "bad" but it's definitely more fun to work with my Backdrop sites. Nowadays I'd build two or even all of the three sites in Backdrop (which I didn't know at that time).

Recently we've built another D8 website. I guess to build it with Backdrop would have been difficult, so using D8 was okay in this case. While some things in D8 are overly complex and it needs a lot of resources, there are also some nice features. I'd say, with the right team, it can be okay to work with it.
Apart of that, maybe you can upgrade the D7 sites to Backdrop!

I use D8 daily for my main job. The sites are huge, enterprise/corporate things (like the Socialists/Democrats European political party website). I've had to learn D8 as part of my work, but it pays the bills, so even though I'd prefer working with Backdrop 24/7 there's nothing wrong with working with Drupal if it pays well :wink:
The pay number would be the same but it's worth more where I'd be going.

I also work with D8 as my main job ...but not exclusively; all new sites we build seem to be D8 - existing D7 sites are more though. All our customers are either enterprise or government, which means that they have the budget to build in D8/D9 or allocate their budget to migrate their existing D7 site to D8/9 in the next year or two ...we have ditched all our "legacy" customers (a couple Joomla, a couple Magento, a bunch of WordPress etc.) ...working with D8 is not bad, but the specific use case (GovCMS) does make certain things tricky (allowing config sync/management, while at the same time locking things like module enabling/disabling and permissions for SaaS customers etc.) ...the overall complexity has increased, and the size of the team required to manage sites has also grown + "expensive resources" needed to be hired (senior developers and Tech Leads).
It‚Äôs a small team and I would be the Drupal guy.
In that case @Justin Keiser I wouldn't worry if I were you ..."one eyed is king among blinds" as they say :sweat_smile:

I also built a site in D8 recently (and will move my Commerce customer to D9). If you have developers available at any time, D9 can be a good fit. But it's not for websites anymore, it's for building digital platforms and develop them over the years. Don't try to build websites on a budget, or on a regular basis (small web agency).
I‚Äôm taking that other gig. The cost of living difference turns into a bit over 20% raise. I‚Äôll still use and advocate for Backdrop though.
Good luck with your new gig @Justin Keiser
Congrats on the new gig @Justin Keiser ! I've found Drupal 8 isn't that bad as long as you don't look at the code, and have something else to do while all the admin pages are loading :)
oh, wait I forgot composer. You also need something else to do while composer is rebuilding. Like maybe working on Backdrop issues :D (it's what I do, anyway...)
